title: Uploads from IFRC, with geodata
name: Uploads from IFRC, with geodata
description: This is a kml of photos from Flickr.com from IFRC's photostream.

properties.name: Aja's story: sewing for life
properties.description: Open photo page Aja Muhibbah, chairwoman of the Pasi Janeng village women’s tailoring group, has a tough job coordinating the work of its 10 members. The women received a livelihood grant of Rp. 17 million (around £960) from the British Red Cross, which they used to buy sewing machines and a generator. For the Pasi Janeng tailors, it has been a steep learning curve. “In terms of business knowledge, I am not a clever person,” says 36-year-old Aja. “Now we are getting orders, and we are trying to expand. It is difficult when there is competition.” The women come together three times a week in their bright, spacious workshop in the local school. It was rebuilt after the tsunami destroyed many of the buildings in this picturesque coastal village on Pulo Nasi island, off the northern tip of Aceh province. The group has seven sewing machines, both manual and automatic. Most of their work comes from other people in the village. The biggest order so far has been curtains for the village school, and they have also made clothes and pillow cases. All their transactions are carefully recorded in a neat ledger, and they have their own bank account. So far only half the group are skilled enough to do tailoring work, including 22-year-old Marwiyah who started learning before the tsunami. “It’s a bit hard to organise lots of people. There are no complaints, but some members are not as good as others,” says Aja. Before receiving the group grant, some of the women earned money sewing individually. Now they can see the positive side of working together. “This way, we get the work done faster and it’s more efficient. Also we can learn from each other,” Aja explains. For more information: <a href="http://www.ifrc.org" rel="nofollow">www.ifrc.org</a> Photo: IFRC (p18120)Taken on 17th June, 2008 by IFRCred,  indonesia,  cross,  grant ... Anyone can see this location

properties.name: Hadi's story: a poultry farm as a livelihood
properties.description: Open photo page At Hadi Marhento’s poultry farm in Teunom village on the west coast of Aceh province, two customers climb into the chicken shed and choose a pair of birds. The women look on slightly squeamishly as the chickens are quickly slaughtered, de-feathered and chopped up ready for cooking. The 37-year-old poultry seller says he’s been busy in the past few days thanks to a local Muslim festival. He explains how he started the business after the tsunami, using the livelihood cash grant he received from the British Red Cross to buy chicks. He reared them for sale, but soon found it more profitable to buy older birds and offer a butchery service. “I saw the market conditions were suitable – not so many people selling chickens yet – and so I carried on with this business using the capital I received from the Red Cross,” Hadi says. “Then I got another 4 million rupiah (£225), which I used to buy a machine for plucking chicken feathers. Since then, I have a good life.” Usually he sells around 300 chickens and 100 ducks a month, producing an average profit of around 4 million rupiah. He employs a young lad to help him with the business and would like to expand it when he has enough capital. Hadi also received a house from the British Red Cross because his old home was destroyed by the tsunami. As with most beneficiaries in the area, the Red Cross helped him secure an official land title. But Hadi is wary of following the example of some others who have used their property as collateral for a loan from the bank. “It seems a bit like gambling,” says Hadi. “I am aware that I’d have to pay back money to the bank every month and that could be a problem if business doesn’t go well.” His income depends on the health of the chickens delivered from the wholesaler in Medan, the main city in neighbouring North Sumatra province. Another risk is avian flu, which has been circulating among Indonesian poultry since early 2004. The virus can be transmitted to people who come into contact with sick or dead birds. For more information: <a href="http://www.ifrc.org" rel="nofollow">www.ifrc.org</a> Photo: IFRC (p18124)Taken on 11th January, 2010 by IFRCman,  indonesia,  august,  aceh ... Anyone can see this location

properties.name: Haiti Earthquake - destruction as seen from the plane
properties.description: Open photo page Photos taken of Haiti’s capital Port-au-Prince during a joint Red Cross Red Crescent / ECHO aerial assessment mission on 13 January 2010. The devastating destruction that was caused by a 7.3 magnitude earthquake on 12 January 2010 is clearly visible. Photo: ECHO For more information: <a href="http://www.ifrc.org/haiti" rel="nofollow">www.ifrc.org/haiti</a>Taken on 12th January, 2010 by IFRChaiti,  earthquake,  echo,  january ... properties.name: Haiti Earthquake 2010
properties.description: Open photo page Destruction and devastation in Haiti after the earthquake. Haitians have never experienced and earthquake in living memory. Many were seen walking the streets shocked and dazed. properties.name: Philippines after the 2009 typhoon season
properties.description: Open photo page The Philippines were hit by four strong typhoons within a few weeks at the end of September/beginning of October 2009. The storms brought so much water that many houses will remain submerged until February/March 2010. Philippines Red Cross is assisting the survivors. In addition to fresh water, sanitation and shelter are priorities. Unfortunately, a lack of funds means that many people don't receive the assistance they need. For more information: <a href="http://www.ifrc.org/Docs/News/09/09123001/index.asp" rel="nofollow">www.ifrc.org/Docs/News/09/09123001/index.asp</a> Photo: IFRC (p- PHL0177)Taken on 25th October, 2009 by IFRCwater,  october,  flood,  philippines ... Anyone can see this location
